posts.post_content: In Standard, Jace Beleren has a secret text box. It reads, "[Vindicate](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Vindicate) target [Jace, the Mind Sculptor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Jace, the Mind Sculptor)."

In Standard, Jace Beleren has a secret text box. It reads, "Vindicate target Jace, the Mind Sculptor."
Report Abuse  
Posted By: Bigg_ol_FATTKIDD (8/4/2010 1:07:04 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I think lil' Jace actually still has some playability in standard. He's not Mind Sculptor, true, but he does have a few significant advantages over big jace:  
  
1. He costs 1 less. This is actually pretty significant, as mind sculptor competes with lots of other good 4 drops- like Day of Judgement.  
  
2. His +2 does something for you immediately. Fatesealing just isn't that good, and you almost always need to do it immediately to put big jace out of lightning bolt range. The howling mine effect is, in most cases, superior for the control decks that tend to play jace.  
  
3. His final ability is easier to activate. It costs less, and it's just easier to protect jace long enough for him to 'go off' with a constant howling mine effect than it is to protect a constant fateseal.  
  
4. He doesn't cost 80$ a pop.
posts.html:
I think lil' Jace actually still has some playability in standard. He's not Mind Sculptor, true, but he does have a few significant advantages over big jace:

1. He costs 1 less. This is actually pretty significant, as mind sculptor competes with lots of other good 4 drops- like Day of Judgement.

2. His +2 does something for you immediately. Fatesealing just isn't that good, and you almost always need to do it immediately to put big jace out of lightning bolt range. The howling mine effect is, in most cases, superior for the control decks that tend to play jace.

3. His final ability is easier to activate. It costs less, and it's just easier to protect jace long enough for him to 'go off' with a constant howling mine effect than it is to protect a constant fateseal.

4. He doesn't cost 80$ a pop.

Posted By: WarpSpider_Ex (8/31/2010 10:16:05 AM)

posts.post_content:
I have to say that I'm not a huge fan of original Jace. Let's consider what happens when you play him (ignoring the Howling Mine effect, since it really isn't good from a card advantage standpoint, though you might use it before he dies):  
  
3 mana  
Draw a card  
Dies to bolt, shock, or an attack with any power 2+ creature  
  
3 mana  
Draw 2 cards  
Dies to bolt, shock, etc  
  
3 mana  
Draw 3 cards, dies  
  
Would I pay 3 mana for a cantrip optional (for the opponent) [Fog](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Fog)? I doubt it.  
Would I pay 3 mana for [Divination](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Divination) plus an optional [Fog](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Fog)? Now that sounds better.  
Would I pay 3 mana for 3 cards? Hell yes.  
  
The problem, however, is that your opponent gets to decide how good he is. If he hits Jace with an attack or bolt after one card, I always feel like I've wasted 3 mana. If he spends a card to kill it, at least I'm up a card (1 card spent , 1 card drawn, opponent played 1 card), but if he kills him with an attack, I've just spent 3 man... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content: this card rocks the socks and i have it in a blue mill/artifact deck (i only play for fun so it is open format)...add some jace erasure's and tome scour and millstone and this is a steady way to make your opponent deck out, adding stuff to make you draw cards accelerates the milling via the jace's erasures and before ya know it you have ten counters on berelen and pop...game over...if the mill doesn't work i usually manage to have a bunch of artifacts and play broodstars and clones of them, steel overseer doesn't hurt either...i'm thinking of adding tezz to this and having something pretty special

posts.post_content: It's interesting how many blue/white control decks run 1,2, or even 3 copies of little Jace now, alongside their 2/3 copies of big Jace. Sun Titan has really increased his playability, and so has mana leak, since you just don't want to be tapping out that often these days, particularly not on turn 4. The move towards permission control and away from tap-out means that little Jace has really started to shine post-m11.
posts.html:
It's interesting how many blue/white control decks run 1,2, or even 3 copies of little Jace now, alongside their 2/3 copies of big Jace. Sun Titan has really increased his playability, and so has mana leak, since you just don't want to be tapping out that often these days, particularly not on turn 4. The move towards permission control and away from tap-out means that little Jace has really started to shine post-m11.
